Another nilpotence theorem

Apr 6, 2020

In the previous post, we described a way of proving the nilpotence theorem, at least at . But it sorta felt like cheating: we relied on the Hopkins-Mahowald -theorem to conclude. In this post, I would like to describe another nilpotence theorem, and a generalization to arbitrary height will appear in my forthcoming paper.

Recall that the Hopkins-Mahowald theorem told us that the free -ring with is . This implies that if is an -ring, and is such that and has zero -Hurewicz image, then is nilpotent. Our goal is to prove the following. There is another Hopkins-Mahowald theorem, telling us that the Thom spectrum of the map

is equivalent to . The main result of this post is the following.

Theorem: The Hopkins-Mahowald -theorem implies that if is a -local -ring spectrum, and is a class with trivial -Hurewicz image such that:

  • in ; and
  • the Toda bracket contains zero;

then is nilpotent.

Proof: We claim that the composite

is null. To show this, we recall another construction of the map . (This construction has nothing to do with .) There’s an old result (due to Selick? I’m not gonna try to find the reference right now) stating that retracts off , where, recall, . This splitting is compatible with the canonical map in the following sense. The -torsion element defines a map , and hence a map , which we’ll abusively denote . Then, the following composite is homotopic to the canonical map :

where the first map is a retraction of off .

Back to : a slight bit more work shows that the above discussion implies that the map is homotopic to the composite

where the final map is the extension of along the double suspension .

So, in order to achieve our goal of showing that is null, it suffices to show that the composite

is null. Since this composite is one of double loop spaces, it further suffices to show that the composite

is null. The bottom cell of maps trivially to , because the bottom cell detects (by our discussion above), and is nullhomotopic in . Therefore, the map factors through the top cell of . The resulting map

detects an element of the Toda bracket , but this contains zero by hypothesis, so is nullhomotopic.

OK, now, since the map is null, the Hopkins-Mahowald -theorem implies that there is a ring map . In particular, the composite of the map with the unit factors as the composite

The middle map, however, is null, because has zero -Hurewicz image. Therefore, the element is null, and hence is contractible. We win!
